Copy and paste the links to all 4 submissions and submit for this assignment. Do not submit the problems that we did together in class.
name: Leetcode! Choose 4!

description:
Summary

In this project you will design a database and create a natural language interface to it using AI. 

Questions to Ask Yourself

  • How good is GPT at generating SQL?
  • What are the limitations and capabilities?
  • Can you use GPT capabilities as a software engineer?
  • Do you know the limits and costs of using GPT?

Read a Published Paper

  • Read this paper! Learn about the three prompting strategies presented - https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11853

Build

  • Design a database! If you have a hard time coming up with an idea of what to model, maybe try one of these (restaurant, university, hair saloon, system for tracking pianos on campus, vending machines, etc..)
  • Build an app that can ask questions of ChatGPT and get answers in the form of SQL queries to your database. Take the results of the queries (if they worked) and get ChatGPT to give a friendly answer using the results from the query on your database. Question -> GPT -> SQL -> Results -> GPT -> Friendly response. It doesn't need to have a GUI or be interactive.

What you will post in Teams (as a group of 0-5 people)

  • Working code files (and DB if using SQLite). Remember :), never share your Open AI API key or OrgID.
  • One+ sentence description or purpose of your database
  • Picture of Schema
  • Sample question, SQL query, response that worked (if you have one)
  • Sample question, SQL query, response that did not work (if you have one)
  • A file outlining at least 6 other examples.
  • Describe somewhere which prompting strategies you tried and if you noticed a difference between them. (Note my post only does two of three - which is fine!).

This assignment is meant to be creative and fun. Feel free to experiment and try new things.

Review

  • Please take a look at other's posts. Please read, then react with a reply or emoji to at least 3 posts of others! Please start by reviewing those posts with less reactions so everyone's projects can be read/reviewed. I'm not asking you to criticize other's work, but please do share feedback or ask questions if something is unclear!

Each Person

You can work in groups of 0-5 people. However, each person needs to:

  • Read the paper https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11853
  • Create a schema picture
  • Contribute to the database design (maybe a table, foreign key, attribute, something!)
  • Execute the program with their *own* API key (or have done this in the past - I just would like to ensure everyone has *used* open ai's API with their own key)
  • Experiment with a question that they came up with!
  • Self report in Canvas

Hopefully Helpful Notes

  • See the post in the Teams from my (with my source code)
    • I recommend you write your own code, work brings learning that you cannot get in any other way! Feel free to look at my code and Dr Jenkins code as well.
    • My code: https://github.com/byu-cs-452/byu-cs-452-class-content/tree/main/aisql 
    • Sample Post: https://github.com/byu-cs-452/byu-cs-452-class-content/blob/main/aisql/sample_post.md 
    • Dr Jenkins Fall 2023 project example: https://github.com/porterjenkins/byu-cs452Links to an external site.
  • Create a new OpenAI Account or pay the $5. This should be enough to complete the assignment. (Cost me 29 cents in including all my debugging)
  • Setup a developer API KEY, find your "ORGID". Learn how to interface with OpenAI. Learn about different models and their costs (GPT 3.5, davinci, GPT 4, etc). Search google to find more information.
  • To create a schema picture using SchemaCrawler (mysql is prettier) I did this:
    • schemacrawler --server sqlite --database .\aidb.sqlite --command=schema --output-file=./schema.png --info-level=standard
    • I had to install Java JRE and scoop to install schemacawler.
    • If you are doing MySQL you can use the MySQL Workbench -> database -> reverse engineer. Actually even if you were doing any language you could modify your create statements and additionally setup a new schema in MySQL Workbench to view the ERD. Other SQL tools give you an ERD for free as well

You can code it up yourself... Here are my *times* for doing this work:

SQL DB AI Project

 

Professor times:

  • Deciding on tech stack 10 minutes (I chose postgresql and python).
  • Creating an API Key on openai 4 minutes ().
  • Read research paper on 3 prompting strategies “zero-shot, single-domain, and cross-domain” 30 minutes.
  • Remembering to pick an AI model 5 minutes (chose latest “gpt-4-1106-preview”)
  • Program architecture and readme.md (15 minutes 1:47pm)
  • Decided on database idea “dog show” and changed from postgres gcloud which is expensive to SQLLITE (13 minutes 2:05pm)
  • Create table statements (manually created with foreign keys), sql python, chatgpt code, (65 minutes 3:10pm)
  • Debugging first prompt strategy to just return sql 52 minutes
  • Working ok 4:40pm (38 min)
  • Next morning started 9am, found way to get “schemacrawler” and generate a picture of my schema ( schemacrawler --server sqlite --database .\aidb.sqlite --command=schema --output-file=./schema.png --info-level=standard)  9:22am (22 minutes)
  • Project description for class 10:48am (82 minutes)
  • Trying out multi-shot: 10 more minutes
  • Making post: 20 minutes
  • Should be ~ 6 hours for the project for a single person to do it on their own from scratch (without copy/pasting code - please do write the code yourself, you'll learn more! :)).

 

\nks to an external site.InNoNoLinks to an exLinks to an external site.

 

How to generate ERD (DB picture) from the schema on MySQL workbench:
name: Natural Language SQL Project

description:
Download Notebook

To run Spark you will need two packages:

  • pyspark - can be installed with pip - pip install pyspark
  • java - you can use the latest version of java. Needs to be the jdk (https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/downloads/)
    • Choose Mac, Windows, or Linux

Alternatively you could use https://colab.research.google.com which will have the JVM and network already configured.

Questions: 

download

  1. Find the top 10 most occurring words in the bible.
    Note: Be sure to ignore case and punctuation and eliminate the blank lines.

Turn in a .pdf or .ipynb file that contains your spark program and the resulting list of the top 10 most occurring words.
name: Install Spark and Hello Spark World

description:
Download Notebook

Download the us-counties.csv data file found at: https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data (Links to an external site.)

    1. Write code to define the schema and then read in the dataset
    2. Write code to find the county with the most deaths
    3. Write code to find the county with the most cases
    4. Write code to find the total number of deaths in Utah county
    5. Write code to find the death rate for each state and sort the states by death rate descending
    6. Write code to something else interesting with this data – your choice

Notes:

Write the code using Spark DataFrames and/or SparkSQL API

NOTE: Deaths and cases are cumulative values through the indicated date for that county, not the number of deaths and cases on that date.

Please turn in a .pdf or .ipynb of your whole program and mark the sections of code for each part of the question.
name: SparkSQL

description:
The easiest way to get Redis up and running is to use the Redis Cloud. Go to https://redis.com/redis-enterprise-cloud/overview/ and click on "Try Free" and sign up for a free account. Once you are in, you should be able to create a free database instance of Redis by choosing a Cloud Platform (I chose Google Cloud Platform) and clicking "Let's Start Free". 

If you click on your database in the control panel that should appear after you clicked on "Let's Start Free", you should see the settings for your database. There are many settings but the important ones for now are:

  • Public Endpoint: Made up of a url and a port
  • Default User
  • Default User Password

You will need these values to connect to your now running Redis database.

A good client to connect to your database is RedisInsight available at https://redis.com/redis-enterprise/redis-insight/

In RedisInsight, you can "Add Redis Database" which will open a settings dialog where you will enter the information for your Redis database. Then you should be able to click on your database and get a connection to it. 

RedisInsight opens up in the Keys view (notice the highlighted key icon on the left). There is a refresh button in the Keys panel. Initially, you won't have any keys to display.

Clicking on the Workbench (looks like a document) icon on the left will take you to a panel where you can enter Redis commands and run them.

To test if everything is up and running, run a ping command

ping

You should get PONG in response

 

Now, go through the tutorial at:

https://auth0.com/blog/introduction-to-redis-install-cli-commands-and-data-types/

Start at Write, Read, Update, and Delete Data in Redis and walk through the rest of the tutorial.

 

Python is a great tool for accessing and using Redis. You will need to install the redis module

pip install redis

Now you can write a simple application using redis. Try this one to start you off:

import redis

import time


# Establish a connection to the Redis database 0 at 

host = ''       # Enter your redis hostname
port = 0        # Enter your redis port
password = ''   # Enter the password for your redis database

r = redis.Redis(host=host, port=port, password=password, db=0)


# SET hello world

r.set('hello', 'world') # True


# GET hello

world = r.get('hello')

print(world.decode()) # "world"




# SET bye "In 60 seconds, I'll self-delete" EX 60

r.set('bye', "In 60 seconds, I'll self-delete", ex=60) # True

expiring_message = r.get('bye')

print(expiring_message.decode()) # "In 60 seconds, I'll self-delete"


# Wait 60 seconds

time.sleep(60)


# GET bye

expired_message = r.get('bye')

if expired_message == None:

    print('key "bye" is not there anymore.')

else:

    print(expired_message.decode()) # "None"







# DEL hello

r.delete('hello')

ans = r.get('hello')

if ans == None:

    print('key "hello" is not there anymore.')

else:

    print(ans.decode()) # "None"

Copy and paste the code into a file named redishello.py  and then run it using:

python redishello.py

Or, you can download redishello.ipynb and run it in a Jupyter Notebook.

If you run redishello.ipynb on Google Colab, you will need to add a cell at the beginning of your notebook with the following:

!pip install redis


Image Deep Learning

Now to see if we can understand something built with redis! This app has separate processes that use redis to build a queue of work and process the queue. This model works fine with one or two clients, but you would likely cause troubles to have a something that "polls" a database.

https://www.pyimagesearch.com/2018/02/05/deep-learning-production-keras-redis-flask-apache/

Go through the tutorial until you reach the "Configuring our deep learning production environment" section

 

Tutorial Files Download Zip: https://byu.instructure.com/files/8307155/download?download_frd=1 

You will need to change in "settings.py" the REDIS_HOST, REDIS_PORT, and REDIS_PASSWORD with the correct information for your redis database.

 

You will need to install a few modules on your own machine if you want to run it on your laptop.

pip install tensorflow

pip install flask

pip install pillow   (or pil)

pip install redis

 

The tutorial has you install and configure the Apache web server. You don't need to do this to play with this image classifying server. Just open three shells. In the first one, run the Flask web server using:

python run_web_server.py 

In the second shell, run the model server using:

python run_model_server.py

In the third shell, you can test it using:

python simple_request.py 

or

python stress_test.py 

 

 

 

Pass Off:

Answer the following questions:

  • What is the name of the key in redis that holds the images submitted from run_web_server.py in Redis?
    • There are two "things" using keys in this little program. One is a queue of work for the "model_server". That item in redis is a list and holds the actual **image** (the key for it is static). The other key(s) used are for storing the results of processing the image (not the image itself.
  • How are the prediction results returned by run_model_server.py  into Redis and retrieved by run_web_server.py? 
    • Please describe how this works using words.
  • Report the results from running simple_request.py with this image:

 

Extra credit:

  • Fix the worker code so you can have multiple workers and not redo work
  • Implement notifications on the front end side
  • Other improvements?

 

Struggling to get your python environment or VSCode to work? Maybe try forking this replit and doing it online:

https://replit.com/@MichaelReynol11/452redislearningproject
name: Redis (Not Ready)

description:
This assignment is a brief intro into neo4j and how GraphDBs work. We'll start with a tutorial using a movie graph and end with the ArXiv tutorial found on here: https://towardsdatascience.com/create-a-graph-database-in-neo4j-using-python-4172d40f89c4

Note: The code from the ArXiv tutorial is all in the Jupyter notebook linked below, except for the query to find the number of papers in each category. The query in the tutorial uses older and deprecated Cypher syntax, and here is new Cypher syntax that works (which is also in the notebook):

query_string = '''
MATCH (c:Category)
RETURN c.category, apoc.node.degree(c, "<IN_CATEGORY") AS inDegree 
ORDER BY inDegree DESC LIMIT 20
'''

top_cat_df = pd.DataFrame([dict(_) for _ in conn.query(query_string)])
top_cat_df.head(20)

Here is a notebook to help you get started:

neo4j_lab.ipynb

Pass Off:

Turn in a pdf file with the following

  1. Graph of the Bacon Path for Nora Ephron using the Movies dataset - a screen shot of the Neo4j Browser with the graph is sufficient.
  2. A screen shot of the inDegree vs Category Name chart from your working jupyter notebook for the ArXiv tutorial (linked at the beginning).
  3. Report the total number of papers from all cs categories as one total amount. 
    • The query is similar to the query used in the ArXiv database tutorial but you will need to use 
      • the where clause
      • the starts with operator
      • either the count() or the sum() aggregation  (maybe distinct?)
  4. The query used to get the total number of papers in all cs categories as one total amount from number 3.
    • Explain whether you wrote a query of all the unique papers in CS categories or whether you wrote a query that additionally counts a paper for each CS category it participates in (either is fine, I just want you to explain which one you did)! Maybe do it the other way for fun.
  5. Have fun and experiment with this technology, do something, or query something that would be interesting to you!
name: GraphDB (Almost Ready)

description:
Your task is to create a database design for a blood bank. You should create a Entity Relationship Diagram for the database to meet the following needs. Use whatever tools you want to create the diagram. You should submit a pdf file of the diagram when you are finished. Your diagram should contain all the needed attributes (including primary and foreign keys) and should be able to answer the questions.

The blood bank has donors and staff (who may also be donors). You will need to keep track of their name (first, last), address (street, city, state, zip), phone number, age, and gender. For donors, you will also need to store blood type and RH factor, medications (name, amount) the donor is taking, and any medical conditions (name, seriousness level) the donor has. This is a large operation that has multiple locations. You will need to keep track of the locations addresses (street, city, state, zip), phone number and the staff that work at each location. Staff may be assigned to multiple locations. Staff have different job roles and are paid based on their role and the time they have worked for the blood bank. You will also need to keep track of all donations (donor, date, amount, location, notes). 

(It is fine to assume each staff member is hired for exactly one role, alternatively, you could allow for them working in multiple roles if you'd like.)

 

Note: the book differentiates between a table diagram and an ERD but the terms are used interchangeably in the industry. What we specifically want in this instance is what the book refers to as a table diagram.

 

Some of the questions you should be able to answer:

  • What are all the times a given donor has donated to the blood bank? 
  • What is the total amount of blood donated by a given donor?
  • Where did the donor last give blood?
  • Who works at a given location?
  • What are the medical conditions of a given donor?
  • Who has a given medical condition?
  • What is the average age of the donors with a given medical condition?
  • How many donors are taking a given medication? who are they?
  • How many staff are donating?
  • What are the common medications used by donors with a given medical condition?
  • How much should a certain staff member be paid?

 

Deliverables:

  • PDF file with the ER Diagram.
name: Midterm ER Diagram

description:
I believe each of you will change the world for the better! This project is intended to give you freedom to explore how to build a highly scaled system that supports reads and writes. My sincere hope is that you can use this experience to be better prepared for your life mission to lead and contribute to amazing future technologies.

The project is very open and should be fun for you! Please pick an idea that you can enjoy working on! Below is a list of requirements that each project needs. Please reach out to me with any questions or concerns!

Project can be done alone or with a team. If you idea is super grand you are working alone you may only get to designing the the system or even pieces of the system. Maybe you can create a working prototype or "proof of concept". Hopefully you can pull together an actual functional and scalable system and the next step will be to find adopters or investors. 

Please aim to spend at least 10 to 20 hours on this project.

System must have:

- Requires reads and writes to some data.
- Something about it that is interesting to you!


System must have at least 3 of the following (if you have another idea let me know!):

  • Interface with some data that you do not own but can query for at runtime or cache periodically (e.g. Google account profile information, weather, US holidays, etc...)
  • Caching layer non-persistent (e.g. Redis) and persistent layer (e.g. Postgres SQL). Pick one of these strategies or come up with your own: cache-aside, query caching, write-behind, write-through, or cache prefetching. (See https://redis.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/redis-enterprise-for-caching.pdf)
  • Support 5000 read requests per second with subsecond average latency on each request.
  • Support 5000 write requests per second with subsecond average latency on each request.
  • Support failing over from one datacenter to another in under 1 minute (can you also think of a zero-downtime solution?) (CAP Theorem)
  • Something you plan to release to real customers and make the world a better place.
  • Clearly document data access and security. What makes your customer's data safe? How do you safeguard and control access to the data in the whole system.
  • Solve a concurrency issue.

Written report (posted in Teams) must include the following:

- Summary of the project (one to three sentences)
- A diagram modeling the different parts of your system and the where the scaling bottlenecks are and what the anticipated limits would be. An explanation of why you expect those limits - either from documentation or from empirical data.
- Key learnings from the project (please try to come up with at least 3)
- Explanation of failover strategy if applicable
- Performance characteristics
- Recorded video demonstrating your system, prototype, proof of concept, or a piece of your system in action. If you have no working code but did a design, please record some explanation of the interesting parts (23 seconds)
- Invite others to give feedback and/or ask questions!

In class presentation:
3-10 minute presentation of your project. 2 minutes ask for feedback and genuinely seek to understand others' questions and suggestions. Sign up on google sheets class presentations signup! You can present before you actually implement it (design review) or after you implement it (implementation review)!

Reviewing other's projects and in class presentations:
Listen to, think about, and give feedback on other's projects (both on Teams post and in class).


FAQ

Q: I have no clue what to do or what this project is. What should I do?
A: Talk to someone else in the class, the TAs, and myself. We are all here to help you succeed. 

Q: Why are we doing this?
A: You are a senior in computer science. I would like to give you an opportunity to use our class to put your data modeling, SQL, and/or NoSQL skills to use. I want you to have a great story and project to put on your resume that is really just yours. I want you to have some experience analyzing a system and what issues or bottlenecks it might have. I want you to have experience in technologies that will enhance your future career and opportunities. I want you to realize that you can learn to build something great without someone else telling you exactly what to do!

Q: How will this be graded?
A: We are all counting on you to make the world a better place. The real test is how you will be better prepared or start now to do your life's work. So give it what you can! :) Your grade on this project will be determined by this quiz you fill out (submit as many times as you need to).

Q: I'd really rather not do the in class presentation, could I do something else instead?
A: Please talk yourself into doing the presentation. We love you! We'd love to hear from you and your ideas. If you can't succeed in talking yourself into it, don't don't be too discouraged! There are also extra credit items if you feel you need to make up the points with something else.

 

Q: What does reads and writes mean?
A: This means it can't be static data. Something needs to be at least periodically updating it and something needs to read what has been written at some point. For example a static set of data that you can read real fast, but never changes isn't what we are looking for. Now if you think you have a great idea that is an exception to this, let me know!

 

Q: It is too open ended, I don't know what I'm doing or where to start. What should I do?
A: Please sign up with the TAs or myself and we can help talk you through your ideas or suggest some.

description:
Your task is to create a database design for Discount Tire. You should create an Entity Relationship Diagram for the database. Use whatever tools you want to create the diagram. You should submit a pdf file of the diagram when you are finished. Your diagram should contain all the needed attributes (including primary and foreign keys) and should be able to answer the questions.

 

Discount Tire has customers and mechanics (who may bring in their cars for repairs). You will need to keep track of their names (first and last), addresses (street, city, state, and zip), phone numbers, ages, and genders. These should be sub-entities of a larger "person" table. Keep track of a mechanic's salary so we remember to pay them. We send customers coupons on their birthdays, so keep track of customers' birthdays. We don't care about mechanics' birthdays. There are multiple garages where the mechanics work. You should keep track of the address, phone number, mechanics working at the garage, and number of vehicle lifts for each location. Mechanics may work at more than one garage. Customers own cars. They may own more than one car. Cars can have multiple owners. Cars have make and model. Each car also has tires. Each tire consists of type (spare, winter, summer), tread (a number), brand, date installed, and last rotated. Cars have multiple tires.

 

Data must be normalized.

 

Note: the book differentiates between a table diagram and an ERD but the terms are used interchangeably in the industry. What we specifically want in this instance is what the book refers to as a table diagram.

 

Some of the questions you should be able to answer:

  • How many staff members work at more than one garage? 
  • What is the most common type of tire across a customer's cars?
  • How many mechanics get their tires from Discount Tire?
  • What's a mechanic's favorite type of tire?
  • What is the total number of tires a customer has bought?
  • How many cars has a customer brought in?
  • Who owns a given car?
  • How much do we pay mechanics on average?
  • What is the most common birthday month?
  • Are males more likely to be mechanics or customers?
  • Which garages are able to handle five customers at the same time?
  • How many Cars have bought all of their tires from Discount tire?
  • How many tires are installed on the customer's birthday?
  • What is the average amount of tread left on the tires?
  • What is the most common brand of tire installed?
  • Can my database be expanded?
name: ERD Extra Credit
